question: A deferred tax liability arises when:

options.A: Tax expense exceeds taxes payable in the current period due to temporary differences
options.B: Taxes payable exceed tax expense in the current period
options.C: The company has net operating loss carryforwards
options.D: Permanent differences exist between book and tax income

explanation: A deferred tax liability (DTL) arises when taxable income is less than book income in the current period due to temporary differences, meaning more taxes will be paid in future periods. This occurs when book income exceeds taxable income temporarily (e.g., accelerated tax depreciation creating lower taxable income now).
tip: DTL: taxable now < book now. Future taxes will be higher.

question: A deferred tax asset arises when:

options.A: Taxable income exceeds book income due to temporary differences
options.B: Book income exceeds taxable income permanently
options.C: The company pays estimated taxes
options.D: Tax rates are expected to decrease

explanation: A deferred tax asset (DTA) arises when taxable income exceeds book income in the current period due to temporary differences, meaning lower taxes will be paid in future periods. Examples include accrued expenses deductible for tax when paid, or net operating loss carryforwards.
tip: DTA: taxable now > book now. Future taxes will be lower.

question: Which of the following creates a temporary difference between book and tax income?

options.A: Municipal bond interest income
options.B: Fines and penalties
options.C: Depreciation using different methods/lives for book and tax
options.D: Life insurance premiums on officers where company is beneficiary

explanation: Depreciation differences (using accelerated methods for tax and straight-line for book, or different useful lives) create temporary differences that reverse over the asset's life. The other items are permanent differences—they never reverse because they are either never taxable or never deductible.
tip: Temporary = reverses over time. Permanent = never reverses.

question: All of the following are permanent differences EXCEPT:

options.A: Tax-exempt municipal bond interest
options.B: Fines and penalties
options.C: Warranty expense accrued for book but deducted when paid for tax
options.D: Premiums on life insurance policies where the company is beneficiary

explanation: Warranty expense is a temporary difference—accrued for book in one period but deducted for tax when paid in a later period. The difference reverses when payments are made. Municipal interest, fines, and officer life insurance premiums are permanent differences that never reverse.
tip: Permanent: municipal interest (tax-free), fines (not deductible), officer life insurance.

question: At year-end, the book basis of a depreciable asset is $100,000 and tax basis is $60,000. The tax rate is 25%. What deferred tax amount should be recorded?

options.A: $10,000 deferred tax asset
options.B: $10,000 deferred tax liability
options.C: $40,000 deferred tax liability
options.D: $15,000 deferred tax liability

explanation: Book basis ($100,000) exceeds tax basis ($60,000) by $40,000. This means more depreciation was taken for tax, so future taxable income will exceed book income. Deferred tax liability = $40,000 × 25% = $10,000.
tip: DTL when book basis > tax basis for assets. DTA when book > tax for liabilities.

question: A valuation allowance should be recorded against a deferred tax asset when:

options.A: The tax rate is expected to decrease
options.B: It is more likely than not that some or all of the DTA will not be realized
options.C: The company has any taxable temporary differences
options.D: The DTA exceeds the deferred tax liability

explanation: A valuation allowance reduces a DTA to the amount that is more likely than not (>50% probability) to be realized. Factors considered include future taxable income, tax planning strategies, and the nature and timing of reversals. The allowance is a contra-asset, reducing net DTA.
tip: Valuation allowance: DTA × probability of non-realization (>50% chance of not realizing).

conceptTested: Sources of taxable income for DTA realization
question: When assessing DTA realization, all of the following are considered sources of future taxable income EXCEPT:

options.A: Future reversal of existing taxable temporary differences (DTLs)
options.B: Projected future taxable income exclusive of reversing temporary differences
options.C: Tax-exempt municipal bond interest expected to be received
options.D: Tax planning strategies

explanation: Tax-exempt income does not generate taxable income and cannot be used to realize DTAs. The four sources for DTA realization are: (1) reversal of existing DTLs, (2) projected future taxable income, (3) taxable income in carryback years (if carryback allowed), and (4) tax planning strategies.
tip: Four sources: DTL reversal, future taxable income, carryback, tax planning.

question: Intraperiod tax allocation requires that income tax expense be allocated to:

options.A: Only continuing operations
options.B: Continuing operations, discontinued operations, OCI, and prior period adjustments
options.C: Each quarter of the fiscal year
options.D: Each revenue and expense account

explanation: Intraperiod tax allocation allocates total income tax expense or benefit for a period among continuing operations, discontinued operations, other comprehensive income, and items charged/credited directly to equity (such as prior period adjustments). Each component shows its own tax effect.
tip: Intraperiod: allocate tax to continuing ops, discontinued, OCI, and equity items.

question: Under ASC 740, an uncertain tax position is recognized if:

options.A: It is possible the position will be sustained
options.B: It is more likely than not (>50%) the position will be sustained upon examination
options.C: The position is approved by the IRS
options.D: The company's tax advisor confirms the position

explanation: The two-step model requires: (1) Recognition—a tax position is recognized only if it is more likely than not to be sustained upon examination. (2) Measurement—if recognized, measure at the largest amount that is greater than 50% likely to be realized. Positions not meeting the threshold are not recognized.
tip: Uncertain tax positions: recognize if >50% likely to be sustained.

question: Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using:

options.A: The tax rate in effect when the temporary difference originated
options.B: The enacted tax rate expected to apply when the temporary difference reverses
options.C: The highest marginal tax rate
options.D: An average of historical tax rates

explanation: Deferred taxes are measured using the enacted tax rate(s) expected to apply in the periods when the deferred amounts are expected to be realized or settled. Changes in tax rates require remeasurement of existing deferred taxes, with the adjustment recognized in income from continuing operations.
tip: Use enacted rate expected at reversal. Adjust DTAs/DTLs when rates change.

question: A company has a deferred tax liability of $100,000 measured at a 25% rate. New legislation is enacted reducing the rate to 21%. What adjustment is required?

options.A: No adjustment until the difference reverses
options.B: Reduce DTL by $16,000 and recognize a tax benefit
options.C: Increase DTL by $16,000 and recognize tax expense
options.D: Reduce DTL by $4,000 and recognize a tax benefit

explanation: Original temporary difference = $100,000 / 25% = $400,000. New DTL = $400,000 × 21% = $84,000. Adjustment = $100,000 − $84,000 = $16,000 reduction in DTL. The credit to DTL is offset by a debit to tax expense (benefit).
tip: Rate change: remeasure DTAs/DTLs, adjust through income.

question: Permanent differences affect:

options.A: Deferred tax assets and liabilities
options.B: The effective tax rate reported in the financial statements
options.C: The classification of taxes as current or deferred
options.D: The cash paid for taxes but not tax expense

explanation: Permanent differences cause the effective tax rate (tax expense / book income) to differ from the statutory rate. They do not create deferred taxes because they never reverse. For example, tax-exempt income lowers the effective rate; non-deductible items increase it.
tip: Permanent differences: affect effective tax rate, not deferred taxes.

question: A net operating loss carryforward creates a:

options.A: Deferred tax liability
options.B: Deferred tax asset
options.C: Current tax payable
options.D: Permanent difference

explanation: NOL carryforwards create deferred tax assets because they represent future tax benefits—the ability to reduce future taxable income. The DTA is measured at the NOL amount times the enacted future tax rate. A valuation allowance may be needed if realization is not more likely than not.
tip: NOL carryforward = DTA. May need valuation allowance.

question: Under US GAAP, deferred tax assets and liabilities are classified on the balance sheet as:

options.A: Current or noncurrent based on when temporary differences reverse
options.B: All noncurrent
options.C: All current
options.D: Based on the related asset or liability's classification

explanation: Under ASU 2015-17, all deferred tax assets and liabilities are classified as noncurrent on the balance sheet. The previous requirement to classify as current or noncurrent based on the underlying asset or liability was eliminated to simplify presentation.
tip: All deferred taxes = noncurrent on balance sheet.

question: A company has an unrealized gain on AFS debt securities of $50,000 (pre-tax) and a 25% tax rate. How is this reported in other comprehensive income?

options.B: $37,500 gain (net of $12,500 tax)
options.D: $50,000 gain with tax shown in income from operations

explanation: OCI items are reported net of their tax effects (or before tax with aggregate tax disclosed separately). Tax on OCI item = $50,000 × 25% = $12,500. Net OCI = $50,000 − $12,500 = $37,500. The tax is allocated to OCI, not to continuing operations.
tip: OCI items: show net of tax or before tax with tax disclosed separately.

conceptTested: Interest and penalties on uncertain positions
question: Interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions should be reported:

options.A: Always as interest expense and operating expense
options.B: Always as additional income tax expense
options.C: As either income tax expense or interest/penalties expense, based on accounting policy election
options.D: As a direct charge to retained earnings

explanation: ASC 740 allows an accounting policy choice for presenting interest and penalties on uncertain tax positions. They may be classified as income tax expense or as interest expense and operating expense. The policy must be disclosed and applied consistently.
tip: Interest/penalties on UTP: policy choice—tax expense or interest/operating expense.

question: A company accrues $100,000 warranty expense for book purposes. For tax, warranties are deductible when paid. The tax rate is 21%. What deferred tax entry is required?

options.A: Deferred tax liability of $21,000
options.B: Deferred tax asset of $21,000
options.C: No entry—this is a permanent difference
options.D: Current tax payable of $21,000

explanation: The warranty accrual creates a book liability with no tax basis (deducted when paid). Book basis of liability ($100,000) > Tax basis ($0). For liabilities, when book > tax, a DTA is created. DTA = $100,000 × 21% = $21,000. This represents future tax savings when paid.
tip: Accrued expenses (deductible when paid): create DTA.

question: A company releases $50,000 of its valuation allowance because it now expects to realize the related DTA. What is the effect on the financial statements?

options.A: Income tax expense decreases by $50,000
options.B: Income tax expense increases by $50,000
options.C: Other comprehensive income increases by $50,000
options.D: Retained earnings is directly credited $50,000

explanation: Releasing a valuation allowance increases the net DTA, which reduces income tax expense (or creates a tax benefit). The change is generally recognized in income from continuing operations unless it relates to an item originally charged elsewhere (OCI, equity).
tip: VA release = reduces tax expense. VA increase = increases tax expense.

question: A company receives $60,000 prepaid rent, which is taxable when received but recognized as revenue over 3 years for book purposes. What deferred tax is created in Year 1?

options.A: DTA because more tax is paid now than book income recognized
options.B: DTL because book income exceeds taxable income
options.C: No deferred tax—this is a permanent difference
options.D: DTA equal to the full $60,000

explanation: In Year 1, taxable income includes all $60,000 but book income includes only $20,000 (1/3). The company pays tax now but recognizes income later. This creates a DTA—the company has prepaid its tax. The DTA reverses as book income is recognized in Years 2 and 3.
tip: Prepaid income (taxed when received): DTA because tax > book now.

question: Deferred tax assets and liabilities of the same tax jurisdiction should be:

options.A: Always shown separately
options.B: Netted and presented as a single amount
options.C: Shown gross with a reconciliation in the notes
options.D: Combined with current taxes payable

explanation: Deferred tax assets and liabilities within the same tax jurisdiction are offset and presented as a single net amount. Different jurisdictions (e.g., federal vs. foreign) are shown separately because they cannot legally be offset against each other.
tip: Net DTAs and DTLs within same jurisdiction. Keep different jurisdictions separate.
